content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Check this out. A dog, stands watch over another dog that got hit by a car, protecting it. The dog standing guard is the mother of the dog that got hit. I am trying to find out how both dogs are doing. Any info please post. How can anyone abuse these wonderful creatures? "http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2009/05/15/ac.shot.thursday.cnn I once saw a dog get hit by a car on one of these rural highways. I stopped my car to help, and watched as another dog (definitely NOT related) pulled the first dog off the road. I walked over, that the injured dog expired as I got there. Unbelievable. I felt so bad. The rescuer was moaning and licking, trying to bring his friend back to life. Dave

content: quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by badmac933: I once saw a cat drag its unconscience owner out of their burning house. Are you serious? They had a pet Mountain lion... It's a cat right? However there are MANY stories of cats saving their owners lives in fires by waking the drunken bums up... Dave Neighbor had an Australian shepherd that got into our back lot and I didn't see it when I was out walking and it decided to be possessive about OUR property, that it was standing on... It started for me and next thing that I saw was a furry blur as one of our Toms, shot out of nowhere and nailed it like a sparrow missile... When the fur quit flying, the dog was in AB leaving the area and the cat was standing there with a big bunch of fur in it's mouth and I swear, a grin on it's mug!... The cat was a Maine Coon Cat and about fourteen pounds of fur covered chain saw, at least in that dogs case... From that point forward, I had a new respect for cats and that cat got just about what ever it wanted, in the way of chow and a place to sleep... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Check this out. A dog, stands watch over another dog that got hit by a car, protecting it. The dog standing guard is the mother of the dog that got hit. I am trying to find out how both dogs are doing. Any info please post. How can anyone abuse these wonderful creatures? "http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2009/05/15/ac.shot.thursday.cnn GREAT story, Cracker! Thank you! One minor correction, though: The dog standing vigilance over the other was not the mom. The mom was the one hit by the car. Nonetheless, a remarkable piece of the animal theory of protection of the clan, and it warmed my heart. Someone here posted that they tend to value an innocent animal life over that of a human. And I must confess my agreement. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

reply: GREAT story, Cracker! Thank you! One minor correction, though: The dog standing vigilance over the other was not the mom. The mom was the one hit by the car. Nonetheless, a remarkable piece of the animal theory of protection of the clan, and it warmed my heart. Someone here posted that they tend to value an innocent animal life over that of a human. And I must confess my agreement. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
title: Why Dogs Truly Are Amazing...

content: My dog - Camy kept them in the divorce Ranger with pups: Puppy! And this is my American Shepard, Riley, sniffing out the wee kitten I rescued (story below) The wee kitten. A stray had a litter in one of my storage sheds, and either a dog or another cat got in there and ate them all. We found lots of tails and paws, and a whole lot of blood. But then there was this one. Somehow, it escaped the fate of the others. Camy and I rescued it, and every 2 hours I would wake up and feed it through the night and wipe its little butt with a warm Q-tip per the PetsMart suggestions. It survived a week, but one morning I woke up and it was dead. No idea why. It was just too young to survive without the mom, I guess. I was 34. And when I found it dead in its little box, I cried so hard that my oldest daughter, Danielle, rocked me back and forth as she held me. I didn't care what anyone thought - I still don't. That little kitten survived a week, and I still sweat in the eyes thinking about it. It was the most innocent, precious thing ever. Camy feeding it: Riley "guarding" the wee kitten: And this is where I found her: For an idea of just how young and small it was, here is it in its box with my Zippo next to it: Is it wrong for a man to cry over a kitten he only had one week that died over 4 years ago? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: My son rescued 4 mixed Australian Sheppard pups.....from a dumpster :-( yes some sick SOB placed them in a dumpster. There was NO way the mother could haven got in the dumpster. They were still alive thank god the garbage truck had not come yet. We found good homes for all of them, 1 in particular got a nice 30 acre farm to roam on.

I stopped my car to help, and watched as another dog (definitely NOT related) pulled the first dog off the road. I walked over, that the injured dog expired as I got there. Unbelievable. I felt so bad. The rescuer was moaning and licking, trying to bring his friend back to life. Dave Gawd, thats amazing and sad at the same time. I hate it when people hit a dog or animal and they just keep running over it like it's a POS. If I saw a dog on the road seriously injured by a car I would run him over and put him out of his misery....It would be over quickly. Either way, my experiences in the Army, Iraq/Afghan have really made me cynical.....to the point where I value a dog's life above most people...I actually cringe more if a dog is about to get hit by a car than a person.... War sucks...

content: quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by badmac933: I once saw a cat drag its unconscience owner out of their burning house. Are you serious? They had a pet Mountain lion... It's a cat right? However there are MANY stories of cats saving their owners lives in fires by waking the drunken bums up... Dave Neighbor had an Australian shepherd that got into our back lot and I didn't see it when I was out walking and it decided to be possessive about OUR property, that it was standing on... It started for me and next thing that I saw was a furry blur as one of our Toms, shot out of nowhere and nailed it like a sparrow missile... When the fur quit flying, the dog was in AB leaving the area and the cat was standing there with a big bunch of fur in it's mouth and I swear, a grin on it's mug!... The cat was a Maine Coon Cat and about fourteen pounds of fur covered chain saw, at least in that dogs case... From that point forward, I had a new respect for cats and that cat got just about what ever it wanted, in the way of chow and a place to sleep... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

"http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2009/05/15/ac.shot.thursday.cnn GREAT story, Cracker! Thank you! One minor correction, though: The dog standing vigilance over the other was not the mom. The mom was the one hit by the car. Nonetheless, a remarkable piece of the animal theory of protection of the clan, and it warmed my heart. Someone here posted that they tend to value an innocent animal life over that of a human. And I must confess my agreement. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

reply: GREAT story, Cracker! Thank you! One minor correction, though: The dog standing vigilance over the other was not the mom. The mom was the one hit by the car. Nonetheless, a remarkable piece of the animal theory of protection of the clan, and it warmed my heart. Someone here posted that they tend to value an innocent animal life over that of a human. And I must confess my agreement. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
title: Why Dogs Truly Are Amazing...

content: My dog - Camy kept them in the divorce Ranger with pups: Puppy! And this is my American Shepard, Riley, sniffing out the wee kitten I rescued (story below) The wee kitten. A stray had a litter in one of my storage sheds, and either a dog or another cat got in there and ate them all. We found lots of tails and paws, and a whole lot of blood. But then there was this one. Somehow, it escaped the fate of the others. Camy and I rescued it, and every 2 hours I would wake up and feed it through the night and wipe its little butt with a warm Q-tip per the PetsMart suggestions. It survived a week, but one morning I woke up and it was dead. No idea why. It was just too young to survive without the mom, I guess. I was 34. And when I found it dead in its little box, I cried so hard that my oldest daughter, Danielle, rocked me back and forth as she held me. I didn't care what anyone thought - I still don't. That little kitten survived a week, and I still sweat in the eyes thinking about it. It was the most innocent, precious thing ever. Camy feeding it: Riley "guarding" the wee kitten: And this is where I found her: For an idea of just how young and small it was, here is it in its box with my Zippo next to it: Is it wrong for a man to cry over a kitten he only had one week that died over 4 years ago? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Check this out. A dog, stands watch over another dog that got hit by a car, protecting it. The dog standing guard is the mother of the dog that got hit. I am trying to find out how both dogs are doing. Any info please post. How can anyone abuse these wonderful creatures? "http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2009/05/15/ac.shot.thursday.cnn I once saw a dog get hit by a car on one of these rural highways. I stopped my car to help, and watched as another dog (definitely NOT related) pulled the first dog off the road. I walked over, that the injured dog expired as I got there. Unbelievable. I felt so bad. The rescuer was moaning and licking, trying to bring his friend back to life. Dave Gawd, thats amazing and sad at the same time. I hate it when people hit a dog or animal and they just keep running over it like it's a POS. If I saw a dog on the road seriously injured by a car I would run him over and put him out of his misery....It would be over quickly. Either way, my experiences in the Army, Iraq/Afghan have really made me cynical.....to the point where I value a dog's life above most people...I actually cringe more if a dog is about to get hit by a car than a person.... War sucks... I feel that way anyway and I have never been in a combat zone...sad ain't it?

content: quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by badmac933: I once saw a cat drag its unconscience owner out of their burning house. Are you serious? They had a pet Mountain lion... It's a cat right? However there are MANY stories of cats saving their owners lives in fires by waking the drunken bums up... Dave Neighbor had an Australian shepherd that got into our back lot and I didn't see it when I was out walking and it decided to be possessive about OUR property, that it was standing on... It started for me and next thing that I saw was a furry blur as one of our Toms, shot out of nowhere and nailed it like a sparrow missile... When the fur quit flying, the dog was in AB leaving the area and the cat was standing there with a big bunch of fur in it's mouth and I swear, a grin on it's mug!... The cat was a Maine Coon Cat and about fourteen pounds of fur covered chain saw, at least in that dogs case... From that point forward, I had a new respect for cats and that cat got just about what ever it wanted, in the way of chow and a place to sleep... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Check this out. A dog, stands watch over another dog that got hit by a car, protecting it. The dog standing guard is the mother of the dog that got hit. I am trying to find out how both dogs are doing. Any info please post. How can anyone abuse these wonderful creatures? "http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2009/05/15/ac.shot.thursday.cnn GREAT story, Cracker! Thank you! One minor correction, though: The dog standing vigilance over the other was not the mom. The mom was the one hit by the car. Nonetheless, a remarkable piece of the animal theory of protection of the clan, and it warmed my heart. Someone here posted that they tend to value an innocent animal life over that of a human. And I must confess my agreement. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

Nonetheless, a remarkable piece of the animal theory of protection of the clan, and it warmed my heart. Someone here posted that they tend to value an innocent animal life over that of a human. And I must confess my agreement. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
title: Why Dogs Truly Are Amazing...

content: My dog - Camy kept them in the divorce Ranger with pups: Puppy! And this is my American Shepard, Riley, sniffing out the wee kitten I rescued (story below) The wee kitten. A stray had a litter in one of my storage sheds, and either a dog or another cat got in there and ate them all. We found lots of tails and paws, and a whole lot of blood. But then there was this one. Somehow, it escaped the fate of the others. Camy and I rescued it, and every 2 hours I would wake up and feed it through the night and wipe its little butt with a warm Q-tip per the PetsMart suggestions. It survived a week, but one morning I woke up and it was dead. No idea why. It was just too young to survive without the mom, I guess. I was 34. And when I found it dead in its little box, I cried so hard that my oldest daughter, Danielle, rocked me back and forth as she held me. I didn't care what anyone thought - I still don't. That little kitten survived a week, and I still sweat in the eyes thinking about it. It was the most innocent, precious thing ever. Camy feeding it: Riley "guarding" the wee kitten: And this is where I found her: For an idea of just how young and small it was, here is it in its box with my Zippo next to it: Is it wrong for a man to cry over a kitten he only had one week that died over 4 years ago? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: My son rescued 4 mixed Australian Sheppard pups.....from a dumpster :-( yes some sick SOB placed them in a dumpster. There was NO way the mother could haven got in the dumpster. They were still alive thank god the garbage truck had not come yet. We found good homes for all of them, 1 in particular got a nice 30 acre farm to roam on.
